Cambridge City
MA

City Manager's Agenda Item
CMA 2024 #257
PLACED ON FILE
Dec 2, 2024 5:30 PM

A communication transmitted from Yi-An Huang, City Manager, relative to an update regarding Community Engagement.

Information

Department:City Manager's OfficeSponsors:
Category:Transmitting Communication

Attachments

Version History
  1. Printout

Body

This communication aims to provide a one-year update regarding the City’s community engagement function detailing recent achievements, outputs, and future plans following the Council's commitment to develop a standardized, transparent, and cohesive community engagement plan for the department-wide municipal government. 

 

One year ago, on November 20, 2023, the City Council placed on file City Manager's Agenda Item CMA 2023 #280 providing an update on two items relative to the City’s community engagement function: 

 

1.       Awaiting Report Item #22-40, which requested the City Manager to confer with appropriate City personnel to develop a standardized, transparent, and cohesive community engagement plan for the entire, department-wide municipal government, 

 

2.       and the City Manager’s performance goal to hire a Director of Community Engagement and update the City’s approach to community engagement to ensure greater consistency and best practice sharing across departments. 

 

CMA 2023 #280 identified two areas where improved coordination could enhance the City’s approach to community engagement: 

 

1.       Improved coordination within the function: streamlined best practice sharing, including shared resources for smaller departments. 

 

2.       Improved coordination between the function and department leadership: earlier coordination and a closer working relationship with departments that have community engagement needs. 

 

Additionally, this communication identified three workstreams to help improve coordination in these areas: 

 

1.       Tools: creating a shared digital workspace for resource and best practice sharing among community engagement staff. 

 

 

 

 

2.       Training: launching a general citywide training program for staff to educate departments about community engagement, resources and best practices, and expectations for working with community engagement staff. 

 

3.       Success/Metrics: defining “success” in community engagement and identifying the appropriate metrics to measure success for different activities. 

 

This update seeks to share a brief list of the City’s progress in these areas in the last twelve months: 

 

Hiring a Director of Community Engagement (DCE) 

·         The community engagement leadership working group formed in 2023 continued meeting from November-February to help inform the scope of duties and responsibilities for the Director of Community Engagement, and the planning for the community engagement FY25 budget.  

 

·         On April 29, 2024, the City successfully hired the inaugural Director of Community Engagement (DCE), Jackson Price. The DCE plays a central role in evolving the City of Cambridge's commitment to quality and inclusive public engagement. The DCE will focus on creating opportunities for all voices to be heard and respected, which will lead to stronger relationships and trust between City government and the local community, as well as more sustainable, meaningful outcomes for all involved. 

 

Research & Strategic Outreach 

·         Outreach Efforts 

 

·         In the last seven months, the DCE has conducted extensive outreach, participating in over 70 introductory conversations and interviews with partners across the City including: Cambridge City Councillors, community-based organizations, local leaders, advisory bodies, and City Staff. The DCE will continue this work and holding conversations with a diversity of partners across Cambridge. 

 

·         Knowledge Building 

 

·         The DCE has met with leading public participation practitioners, reviewed regional, national, and international public engagement case studies, assessed digital engagement technologies, and studied academic literature. Attendance at key events, including the International Association for Public Participation Conference and the National League of Cities Summit, further informed this research. 

 

Tools & Improved Coordination 

·         Community of Practice 

 

·         The DCE established a Community Engagement Community of Practice for relevant staff across 12 departments. This group meets monthly to improve city-wide coordination, and to facilitate the exchange of best practices and resources.   

 

·         Digital Toolkit 

 

·         The DCE and Information and Technology Department developed a comprehensive digital community engagement toolkit for City staff featuring a collection of best practices, resources, and a shared community engagement calendar to track and coordinate events. 

 

·         Cross-Department Support 

 

·         The DCE has supported the planning and implementation of community engagement initiatives across departments including: the Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion - Digital Navigators Pilot Program; Central Square Rezoning; Domestic Violence Awareness Month outreach; Meet your Neighbor Day; and the American Freedman Commission preliminary engagement process. 

 

·         Collaboration with Housing Partners.

 

·         The DCE worked with the Cambridge Housing Authority to host a tour of Washington Elms, Newtown Court, and the Manning Apartments and connect community engagement leadership with key resident service providers. Plans for further collaboration with housing providers such as Just A Start and Homeowner's Rehab Inc. are underway. 

 

Output and lessons learned: 

Foundation of Equitable, Inclusive, and Anti-Racist Public Engagement 

·         Civic engagement is critical to the health and wellbeing of a functioning democracy. 

 

·         Cambridge community members want to be informed and have a voice in shaping government decisions that impact their lives. 

 

·         Equitable community engagement is an ongoing collaborative process to build trust and deepen partnership with community to shape and implement policies that impact people’s lives. It is a collective commitment that will require a sustained multi-year effort to reach this goal. 

 

·         Anti-racist public engagement means actively working to identify and dismantle systemic barriers to participation and representation, particularly those that disproportionately affect communities who are marginalized. This may involve shifting existing power dynamics, addressing implicit biases, and centering the experiences and perspectives of Black, Indigenous, and people of color, and other marginalized groups. 

 

Current State of Engagement Affairs 

·         Over the past twenty years, the City has created network of community engagement, communications, and community relations staff spanning more than 14 departments. This team is committed to fostering equitable and inclusive engagement, overseeing a wide range of public initiatives across various departments and topics throughout the year. 

 

·         While many larger departments have staff who primarily focus on community engagement, community relations, or communications, most medium to smaller sized departments do not. There is a need to support these smaller teams’ public engagement efforts. 

 

Key Practices for Effective Engagement 

·         When planning and implementing public engagement processes, the City representatives should: 

 

·         Specify the purpose of the engagement. 

 

·         Define the type of engagement. 

 

·         Select appropriate methods of engagement. 

 

·         Identify metrics to evaluate the effectiveness of engagement methods.  

 

·         Establish a feedback loop to communicate results to participants. 

 

·         Language justice is a critical function of equitable and inclusive engagement, and the City should continue to reinforce its commitment to this practice in FY26. 

 

·         There is significant room to grow in incorporating data to inform and score community engagement exercises.

 

·         Compensation and reciprocity are effective tools to ensure participation from under-resourced and historically underheard communities. 

 

·         The most effective way to engage community members on important community issues is to create spaces that foster active listening, deliberation, and connection. 

 

 

Future plans: 

Strategic Outreach & Tools Development 

·         Continuing outreach, conversations, and interviews with partners across the City including: Cambridge City Councillors, faith-based organizations, community-based organizations, local leaders, advisory bodies, and City Staff. (FY25) 

 

·         Continuing the development and expanding access to the digital community engagement toolkit for City staff. (FY25) 

 

Planning & Frameworks 

·         Creating a city-wide framework for planning and implementing community engagement in FY25 & FY26, specifying: 

 

·         The purpose of the engagement. 

 

·         The type of engagement and the role of participants. 

 

·         The methods of engagement. 

 

·         Metrics to evaluate effectiveness. 

 

·         A feedback loop to participants. 

 

·          Explore opportunities for enhancing the city’s existing approach to Boards and Commissions, a critical community engagement function in the city. This includes building on previous commitments and identifying new ways to leverage the talents and dedication of highly engaged members who are serving their community. (FY25 & FY26) 

 

Capacity Building 

·         Launch a general citywide training program to educate staff on community engagement practices, resources, and expectations. (FY26) 

 

·         Expand the City Manager’s Community Engagement Office’s capacity to support the development and adoption of citywide equitable, inclusive, and anti-racist public engagement strategy in Fiscal Year 2026. (FY26) 

 

Closing thoughts: 

The City of Cambridge is committed to fostering equitable, inclusive, and anti-racist public engagement with our many diverse communities. The City has made progress in implementing the recommendations approved by the City Council in November 2023 and will continue working to improve the community engagement function in fiscal year 2025 & 2026. Thank you to the City Council, staff, and community partners for your support as we strive to make Cambridge a model for equitable, inclusive, and anti-racist public engagement. 

 

 

 

 

Yi-An Huang

City Manager

 

Meeting History

Dec 2, 2024 5:30 PM  City Council Regular Meeting
